comments.commentBody:
This is a perfect example of how individual ambition will result in huge, unanticipated, sweeping changes in society. We have a great system for promoting, no, optimizing the former, and next to nothing to address the latter. Imagine a truly democratic process that decides where in society robots should be, what they should do, and how they should be programmed; and what efforts will be taken when negative consequences materialize.

Can capitalism, a 500 year old idea, work with this 21st c. technology to the benefit of humanity?

@ Tess — The “procedural grounds” you (rather contemptuously) refer to were the complaining witnesses’ refusal to continue coöperating with the court’s orders to appear for pretrial discovery. Since their testimony •was• the principal evidence in the state’s case against Solo, their failure to make themselves available meant the case was dismissed for, in a literal sense, a lack of evidence.

The prosecutors, according to the ESPN article, are not “refiling” the case; they’re appealing the judge’s dismissal. If the sister and nephew won’t coöperate in the legal proceedings, however, it’s hard to see how the case can go forward.

As for your statement, “Ms. Solo would be a frequent (if not permanent) resident of the penal system if not for her athletic skills,” that’s an •astoundingly• sweeping claim. If you’re saying that, were she not a world-class athlete, she’d be serving a life sentence (what else could “permanent” mean?), that must mean you think she’d have been convicted of murder, or some other seriously violent felony. Do you have •any• basis for that statement?!

Or, even if your comment about a “permanent” sentence was just hot air interjected for dramatic effect, what justification do you have for proclaiming that, if an average citizen, Solo would be “frequently” imprisoned? She’s apparently been arrested •once•. Is dissing a coach or teammate, or sending testy tweets, also subject to incarceration? How would •that• add up to “frequent” incarceration?!

— Brian

After watching Sweden uke up two leads to Nigeria, it appears that Sweden is bereft of pace even more than our side is.
Nigeria has pace to burn, but defend worse than a high school team on corners, and their goalie is relentlessly terrible. Could end up 7-6...

Dunn is a local product from a New York State High School powerhouse. In High School and at UNC she played all over the pitch. I've seen her at center half, too. I don't think there's any reason to believe she couldn't deputize in central midfield in a pinch, and there's *every* reason to believe she'd be better than Krieger, klingenberg and/or Chalupny. Those fullbacks look like Achilles' Heels. Combine that with the first half struggle against a high press, and, just wow. Solo's three big saves kept yesterday from being a loss against a side that flat ran out of gas in an hour.
They are just toying with Cleveland. I feel bad for them ( the Cavs ). GS is making the Cavs feel like they have a shot. They do not.

@Dr. John --
Almost all abortions in the US occur in the first trimester, long before the fetus is viable. While some states have banned abortions after the first trimester, or at some point in the second, the following table indicates the % of fetal viability by week of pregnancy, facts which those seeking shorter and shorter limits on abortion should know.

The anti-abortion crowd also should know the critical medical needs of women who require abortions later in the 2nd, or even 3rd trimester because their own lives are threatened by the pregnancy.

Completed weeks of Gestation at birth Chance of survival:
21 and less 22 23 24 25 26 27
0% 0-10% 10-35% 40-70% 50-80% 80-90% >90%
30 34
>95% >98%

The limit of viability is the gestational age at which a prematurely born fetus/infant has a 50% chance of long-term survival outside the womb. With the support of neonatal intensive care units, the limit of viability in the developed world has declined since 50 years ago, but has remained unchanged in the 12. Currently the limit of viability is considered to be around 24 weeks although the incidence of major disabilities remains high at this point. Neo-natologists generally would not provide intensive care at 23 weeks but would from 26 weeks.

The question of what is an "unborn survivable fetus" is a scientific one, not a theological one like "how many angels can dance on the head of a pin?"

Many fetuses are not "viable". Though the unborn fetus hasn't committed any crime, bringing a child into poverty will ensure a painful and difficult life for the parents and the child. It will also practically ensure that most people remain in poverty. Or it will cram more children into our overcrowded adoption system. The life of the adult in any situation trumps the potential life of the fetus. A woman should have the right to do with her body, and her life, as she sees fit.
Dr. John - Check out sites like the one for The Innocence Project, not everyone on death row or who has been executed was guilty.

Wow. Let me get this straight. Texas practically has an express lane for convicts on Death Row, but wants to "preserve life" by imposing restrictions, stumbling blocks & distance between women and their right to choose. Color me confused O_o

@ Diane — No, as to your numbers; you got “101 wins” by subtracting the 6 losses from the 107 total U.S. matches Sundhage coached. But the article clearly states that the U.S. won •91• matches under her. 10 other matches ended as draws.

— Brian
Outlawing theft won't prevent all thefts, nor will outlawing murder in our society, but it doesn't mean the state should endorse these actions.
Well done! This is the kind of thing that makes the puzzle head and shoulders above the rest.

Sorry to break the bad news, but there are a lot of low-intelligence voters out there.

It's very simple. No one is being forced to have an abortion if the woman doesn't want one. But if a woman wants an abortion, it should be no one's decision but hers & her partner, if the partner is involved. I really don't understand why this is such a difficult concept to grasp, especially when the right-wing loudly proclaims that government ought to get out of people's lives. But then again, see my comment above about low-intelligence voters.

Don't misunderestimate us voters. As Stephen Colbert often reminded us, "Trust your gut!"  In our guts we know, the laws of probability will not allow a third Pres. Bush to get us into a war of choice in the Middle East, leave us with more political Supreme Court appointments, and oversee a sinking economy. Right?

Thomas,

It's not "dumb" to point out that the so called "leaders" of the GOP have so little in common with the voters that those same voters would rather see Voldemort than Mike Huckabee, Ted Cruz, Jeb Bush, Rick Santorum, Chris Christie and Donald Trump.
Darn it! I forgot to make friends with a billionaire to bail me out when I can't pay my bills and when I want to run for president.  Where did I go wrong?

Honestly, although Rubio -- just like the rest of us -- is only trying to get ahead with the help of a billionaire to cover his inability to refuse an unnecessary expense, I do think this blog entry is kinda dumb.
Since you know so much about Texas, give some examples where they DON'T have the concern you speak of?
In many other states across the country.  Everywhere these limitations are imposed and funds for mothers and children are cut.
Where is Texas after a child is born into poverty, or with a severe medical need?  Where is the concern then?
By what stretch of he imagination could a vasectomy be compared to an abortion? Wouldn't a vasectomy be more closely compared to a tubal litigation or hysterectomy?

Why aren't women allowed to have abortions on demand when men cn have vascecomies on demand? Who are our Representatives to didctate a woman's right to control her body? She can have free speech but not the freedom of acting on her personal decisions. Women are still slaves of the legislature and the Churches of hate. Pity.
Planned Parenthood is barely mentioned, let alone "other Democratic groups."  Then you go on about hired limousines....  Get a grip.  (And by the way it's "affected" not "effected").
Thank you for raising this point.  I've never understood why the people who oppose abortion get so squirmy about family planning as well.

Oh my.  Did you even look at the maps?  The remaining abortion clinics are not evenly distributed.  Do you seriously imagine that Texas has 'few rural women'?!  Do you imagine that poor Mexican American women on the Texas border travel by limousine?  Does $300M sound like a lot to you?  That's less than $1 per American.  Why would they upgrade clinics that will be shut down regardless (for some other phony reason)?  Have you ever been to a Planned Parenthood?  It's hardly fancy.  Whose 'lavish travel'?

The whole article is just a commercial for donations to Planned Parenthood and other Democratic groups.   There are 41 abortion clinics in Texas. How are they distributed among the population? If some of them close the number of women effected will be minimal. PP could take the few rural women to city abortion clinics in limousines. If you can buy your way out of a problem you don't have problem. Or PP could donate some of its nearly $300M in revenue (2013 latest audited statement on their website. You would think the 2014 data would be available by now) to upgrade the clinics. Problem solved. But spending the funds on clinics would mean less money for salaries and lavish travel and fancy offices etc...

If Greece exits the euro, capital controls, a large devaluation of the drachma, and repudiation of all or some large amount of Greece's debts is certain, but, as you say, leaving the euro and having to reestablish drachma is a different and more difficult than what Iceland faced. So how would a smart economist or his students, as an assignment, design Greece's exit from the euro to minimize the pain and move to recovery and full employment as quickly as possible?

To begin an optimal exist from the euro, Greece would have some bargaining leverage, which would be negotiating terms with the Eurozone for Greece not repudiating all of its debt. Greece could negotiate the amount of debt repudiation for credit and for other assistance.

Next would be the fiscal and monetary policies that Greece should pursue. Would I be wrong in thinking that the Keynesian response would be fiscal and monetary stimuli, which would be based on a Hicksian analysis of the amount and types of monetary and fiscal stimuli that will move Greece's real interest rate from negative to positive territory, and the fiscal measures that will produce the greatest increase in real and potential GDP?

If I am right about the foregoing principles, how would they be fleshed out in actionable policies? And even if Greece does reaches terms with the Brussels Group and thus doesn't abandon the euro, a practical plan for Grexit, based on the foregoing principles, would greatly increase Greece's bargaining leverage.

@AACNY

Fun fact: In the real world, 5th graders actually do sometimes have sex.

Fun fact: What aspects of "sex education" in the program for 5-year olds were objectionable to you. I know I wanted my young children to understand about unwanted touching and other issues one would consider part of sex education.

Fun fact: The rate of unwanted teen pregnancies is, for the most part, highest in red states where sex education is often controlled by the Christian right - that is, states where access to sex education, contraception, and abortion are frowned upon.

https://thenationalcampaign.org/data/compare/1701
No, you don't.  You speak for no one but yourself.

Citizenship, innocence, and complete lack of evidence expecpt perjured testimony are no guarantee of not being railroaded into prison, beaten, driven crazy and suicidal, or judicially murdered in this great country of ours.

@Teddy -

I am an adoptive parent too, and to me, the idea that a woman should carry a child to term to enable me to become a parent is sick.

I am very grateful for the choice my child's birth parents made, to bring my child to life. I am very glad it was a CHOICE.

It would make me sick to my stomach to learn that a woman was forced to carry through with an unwanted pregnancy as a service to prospective adoptive parents.
You really ought to look up the statistics on deaths due to abortions before making such a claim. The number is much lower than many of its enthusiasts would believe.

When you find hacks performing abortions in Texas with coat hangers as was the case nationwide in the 60s and 70s, all the Texas politicians can pat themselves on their collective backs and tout, "I did this and I'm proud!" Shame on all of you for encouraging abortions in your state to go underground.
And I speak for women who as human beings should have the right to determine how they're bodies will be used.

I believe Josy was saying that legality is not as big of a deterrent as some would hope.  If you study the literature, you will see that abortions rates stay relatively consistent, regardless of local laws.
Bush was never legally elected. Twice. He was appointed by a corrupt Supreme Court in 2000. He was returned in 2004 due to massive proven electronic voter fraud in Florida and Ohio.
Robert, it's on its way to becoming "one of those countries."

Jurisdictions with the most stringent restrictions on abortion also attempt
to limit or prohibit access to contraceptives. Instead of fewer abortions, they end up with more, though not necessarily legal or safe.
There is interesting wording in that sentence.
Shame on Texans for bringing unwanted babies into their state.
Shame on Texas for trying to reduce the destruction of human fetuses.
